Instrument.name: Ultraviolet Spectrometer for VG1
Instrument.description: The Ultraviolet Spectrometer (UVS) instruments on board of Voyager 1 & 2 are almost identical and record the entire spectrum, within its range, with a single exposure. The instrument measures atmospheric properties of outer planets and their satellites, as well as radiation. It is a compact Wadsworth mounted objective grating spectrometer that covers the wavelength range of 0.0535 to 0.1702 micron for Voyager 1, and has no moving parts. The UVS has two spectral resolutions depending on the nature of the source, and can often be improved with spectral analysis. At wavelengths longward of 0.1350 microns there is a slight (~10%) asymmetry in the response on either side of the center of the field of view (FOV). Wavelengths shorter than about 0.1250 micron strike the MCP directly. Longer wavelengths first pass through a MgF2 filter with a semi-transparent photocathode of CuI. This serves to boost the quantum efficiency at long wavelengths and to reduce the response to second-order light. The UVS transmits the contents of its memory to the flight data system (FDS) on command of the FDS. The optical system consists of 13 aperture plates of the mechanical collimator, establishing a field of 0.1x0.87 degree for the airglow field and 0.25x0.87 degree for the occultation field, and a platinum coated concave diffraction grating, with 540 lines/mm and spherical curvature radius of 400.1 mm. Two modes of electrical operation allow the detector to operate in a photon-counting mode for low source intensities, or in an integration mode for high source intensities.
